samples.question: Do you work or study?
samples.transcript: I do work and study. I study a Bachelor of Commerce at university majoring in Economics and Management. I really enjoy what I study. I enjoy the quantitative side of economics and the qualitative side of management. I also do work outside of university life as well. I work at a high school as an academic advisor where I provide academic support for students in their final years of high school. Wow. All right.
samples.transcript_original: I do work and study. I study a Bachelor of Commerce at university majoring in Economics and Management. I really enjoy what I study. I enjoy the quantitative side of economics and the qualitative side of management. I also do work outside of university life as well. I work at a high school as an academic advisor where I provide academic support for students in their final years of high school. Wow. All right.

I enjoy the quantitative side of economics and the qualitative side of management. I also do work outside of university life as well. I work at a high school as an academic advisor where I provide academic support for students in their final years of high school. Wow.

samples.question: Well, the examiner asked a really short question is, which was, do you work or study?

But I do not think that it needs to talk about what you enjoy, because what happens now is the examiner might have those type of questions later, which are maybe quite a bit of an extension.

And the same thing happens here with Stephen. He probably expanded a little bit too much. You also notice as well that maybe because he is front of, in front of the camera, it is a little bit more difficult for him to speak. you notice he has this kind of, we, in English we say, a frog in your throat. some words are a bit, a little bit difficult to, to come out. So, good start though. I think he is given some really good answers. Well done to Stephen. And you will notice that he is a native speaker. And if you are watching this for the first time, go and watch our Rommie video. Rommie is also an Australian. And I explain why Australians or British or Americans, why they sometimes need to take this test. well, you have told me what you study.

samples.question: Do you enjoy studying this?

It is quite challenging the course since economics is no, since economics is so broad it is quite challenging to grasp the concepts but once I do I really find it very rewarding and very fulfilling. So you will notice that Maddy did have to repeat this question which was do you enjoy what you have, or what you are studying and Stephen had already answered that. A couple of points here. you will notice that he does look a little bit nervous, which is normal. On the test day, you guys are going to be nervous. So this is kind of a, a real life situation. Stephen may have a very minor speech impediment in his everyday life. And that, right, that might affect many people who watch this video.

samples.question: He said to graps, okay?
samples.transcript: Rather than to grasp. He got the P and the S the wrong way around. And believe it or not, this is really common for native speakers to make these tiny slips in their speaking. I understood what he wanted to say. The examiner would probably overlook it. But if he made any more of those mistakes, they probably would not be so lenient and they might mark him down a little bit. Again, nerves. it is a little bit of a struggle to get things out at times, but so far so good. Really well supported and extended answers.

samples.question: And has anyone ever surprised you with something?
samples.transcript: No, they have not because I, because they know how much I dislike surprises, especially gifts. But I have been to a few surprise birthday parties and chip and contributed to a few surprise gifts for people and, and it is surprising that I do not like surprises myself, but I like giving other people surprises. Stephen, I am so disappointed because you are going to use some really great language here to mean to contribute. So he talked about going to a birthday party or a surprise birthday party where people contributed. And if you listen back, if you go back and play again, you will notice that he said ch, ch, and I know what he was going to say. He was actually going to say, we chipped in. And everybody in the party chipped in to contribute to or to buy a present for the birthday person. And this idea of the word, a phrasal verb, to chip in, means to put some money all together and everybody collectively buys the present. So recently I chipped in for my friend's birthday and this chip in language is great because it is a phrasal verb, it is idiomatic, it is less common. And he just went down with, he went with the standard word which was to contribute or, to put some money in to buy a friend a gift. So I am just a bit disappointed that he did not use the word chip in because I think that would have been a great learning, tool for you. Now.

samples.question: Do you own a bicycle?
samples.transcript: I do not own a bicycle, but I do enjoy the leisure of cycling. I used, I did own a bike when I was quite young. I rode it when I was in my early childhood days, but I do not ride, I do not cycle anymore. Okay.
samples.transcript_original: I do not own a bicycle, but I do enjoy the leisure of cycling. I used, I did own a bike when I was quite young. I rode it when I was in my early childhood days, but I don't ride, I don't cycle anymore. Okay.

samples.question: Do you think you will have a bicycle in the future?
samples.transcript: I do, I do hope I will have a bicycle in the future. Given the topic of climate change, I want to make sure that I contribute more to reducing CO2 emissions and hopefully choosing a more eco-friendly mode of transport. And not only is it more eco-friendly, it is also great for exercise and physical activity. I do not know about you, but I feel like a couple of these answers feel a little bit rehearsed and like he is practiced them a lot. And I can assure you, I promise you that Stephen had no idea of the questions before coming to this test.

samples.question: And did you learn to ride a bicycle when you were a child?
samples.transcript: I did learn to ride a bicycle when I was a child. Obviously, I started out with the training wheels because it was quite hard to balance. But as time went on, I got used to it, learned to balance myself on the bicycle. And now it is just part of muscle memory. A couple of great features of language here. He used collocations such as training wheels. Training wheels are the wheels that you have as a child on the sides of your bike that prevent you from falling over and he used the word muscle memory. So training wheels and muscle memory are great examples of collocation. Remember these words which are less common but when you fit them together, they make the, the speech much richer. Rather than just giving simple language the whole time, you do need to include some of these idiomatic phrases, expressions, compound nouns, all those things that are less common in language. In the next part of the test, I am going to give you a topic and I would like you to speak for one to two minutes. you will have one minute to think about what you want to say and I will give you a pen and some paper to.

samples.question: And Stephen went down the route of, well, what is the difference between introverts and extroverts?
samples.transcript: Well, that was not really what the question was about.
samples.transcript_original: Well, that wasn't really what the question was about.
samples.transcript_cleaned: that was not really what the question was about.

samples.question: And how does the weather affect outdoor activities?
samples.transcript: I would say the weather greatly affects the way we look at outdoor activities. For example, on a very sunny day like this, we would feel, people tend to feel more motivated to step outdoors since the weather is a lot nicer, the breeze feels nice, and I would say the other way around. with, rainy, cloudy weather, people might not feel as motivated to step outside since, the weather is quite gloomy. Since they do not feel, there is not much of a positive connotation that is associated with, cloudy or sunny or cloudy or rainy weather when stepping, when doing outdoor activities. Again, I would expect that the examiner might jump in there and ask a question related to that topic. it is quite a long section there of Stephen speaking. He did well. He again went a little bit off topic, but he did answer the question. So far, so good.
